evidence.text: Plaintiffs seek, for themselves and the UC researchers class, an injunction that restores their lost funding, enjoins further unlawful grant terminations or suspensions, and provides the grant extensions necessary to enable them to effectively complete the work for which these grants were approved.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiff: injunction restoring lost funding, enjoining further unlawful grant terminations or suspensions, and providing grant extensions necessary to complete research

evidence.text: Plaintiffs, individually and on behalf of all others similarly situated, allege for their Complaint against the below-named Defendants as follows: ... All University of California researchers, including faculty, staff, academic appointees, and employees across the University of California system (“UC researchers”) whose research grants have been or will be terminated, denied, suspended, or reduced by any of the Defendants pursuant to Executive Orders 14151, 14154, 14158, 14168, 14173, 14217, 14238, and/or 14222, and/or other directives of the Trump Administration or DOGE, from and after January 20, 2025.
evidence.source_document: Class Action Complaint for Declaratory and Injunctive Relief

add_extracted.value: Plaintiffs: Class Action

evidence.text: the United States District Court (Illston, J.) stated in its May 22, 2025 Order Granting Preliminary Injunction in American Federation of Government Employees, AFL-CIO v. Trump, Case No. 25-cv-03698-51 (Dkt. 124)

evidence.text: Plaintiffs are likely to succeed on their claims that the termination of grants for research involving blacklisted topics like 'diversity' and 'equity' violates the First Amendment and runs contrary to Congress's specific directives to support research concerning—and foster greater involvement in the sciences of—underrepresented groups.
evidence.source_document: Order Granting Motion for Preliminary Injunction and Provisional Class Certification

add_extracted.value: Court granted preliminary injunction on Plaintiffs' claims that grant terminations violate First Amendment and APA, issued June 23, 2025

evidence.text: Plaintiffs seek this relief on behalf of themselves and a proposed class of similarly situated UC researchers who likewise had their grants terminated via form letters without a reasoned explanation and for researching forbidden topics.
evidence.source_document: Order Granting Motion for Preliminary Injunction and Provisional Class Certification

add_extracted.value: Preliminary injunction halting grant terminations for research on diversity, equity, and inclusion topics

evidence.text: Plaintiffs are six UC researchers who had multi-year grants supporting their research suddenly terminated without explanation. Dr. Neeta Thakur of UCSF, for example, studies how genes in different racial and ethnic groups affect lung disease, and received a federal grant to research ways to mitigate the health risks of wildfire smoke in communities of color and low-income communities.
evidence.source_document: Order Granting Motion for Preliminary Injunction and Provisional Class Certification

add_extracted.value: Plaintiffs are UC researchers whose federal grants were terminated without reasoned explanation for research on diversity, equity, and inclusion topics
